page_content: Section 1: Title and extent of operation of the Code. This Act shall be called the Indian Penal Code, and shall [extend to the whole of India ****]. [cite: 5]

page_content: Section 2: Punishment of offences committed within India. Every person shall be liable to punishment under this Code and not otherwise for every act or omission contrary to the provisions thereof, of which he shall be guilty within [India] 6*** [cite: 6]

metadata.section_title: Punishment of offences committed within India.

page_content: Summary: Section 3: Punishment of offences committed beyond, but which by law may be tried within, India.

metadata.section_title: Punishment of offences committed beyond, but which by law may be tried within, India.

page_content: Section 3: Punishment of offences committed beyond, but which by law may be tried within, India.

metadata.section_title: Punishment of offences committed beyond, but which by law may be tried within, India.

page_content: 3 IPC 3 S. 3 Sec 3 Section 3

metadata.section_title: Punishment of offences committed beyond, but which by law may be tried within, India.

page_content: Section 3: Punishment of offences committed beyond, but which by law may be tried within, India. Any person liable, by any [Indian law], to be tried for an offence committed beyond [India] shall be dealt with according to the provisions of this Code for any act committed beyond [India] in the same manner as if such act had been committed within [India]. [cite: 7]

metadata.section_title: Punishment of offences committed beyond, but which by law may be tried within, India.

metadata.section_title: Extension of Code to extra-territorial offences.

page_content: Section 4: Extension of Code to extra-territorial offences. The provisions of this Code apply also to any offence committed by- ¹⁰[(I) any citizen of India in any place without and beyond India; [cite: 9][cite_start] (2) any person on any ship or aircraft registered in India wherever it may be.] [cite: 10][cite_start] ¹¹/(3) any person in any place without and beyond India committing offence targeting a computer resource located in India.] [cite: 11, 12] ¹²[Explanation. [cite_start]In this section-

metadata.section_title: Extension of Code to extra-territorial offences.

page_content: e located in India.] [cite: 11, 12] ¹²[Explanation. [cite_start]In this section- (a) the word "offence" includes every act committed outside India which, if committed in India, would be punishable under this Code; [cite: 14][cite_start] (b) the expression "computer resource" shall have the meaning assigned to it in clause (k) of sub-section (1) of section 2 of the Information Technology Act, 2000 (21 of 2000).] [cite: 18] Illustrations:

metadata.section_title: Extension of Code to extra-territorial offences.

page_content: of the Information Technology Act, 2000 (21 of 2000).] [cite: 18] Illustrations: A, ³[who is [a citizen of India]], commits a murder in Uganda. [cite_start]He can be tried and convicted of murder in any place in [India] in which he may be found. [cite: 20, 21]

metadata.section_title: Extension of Code to extra-territorial offences.

page_content: Section 5: Certain laws not to be affected by this Act. Nothing in this Act shall affect the provisions of any Act for punishing mutiny and desertion of officers, soldiers, sailors or airmen in the service of the Government of India or the provisions of any special or local law. [cite: 28]

page_content: Summary: Section 6: Definitions in the Code to be understood subject to exceptions.

metadata.section_title: Definitions in the Code to be understood subject to exceptions.

page_content: 6 IPC 6 S. 6 Sec 6 Section 6

metadata.section_title: Definitions in the Code to be understood subject to exceptions.

page_content: Section 6: Definitions in the Code to be understood subject to exceptions. Throughout this Code every definition of an offence, every penal provision, and every illustration of every such definition or penal provision, shall be understood subject to the exceptions contained in the Chapter entitled "General Exceptions", though those exceptions are not repeated in such definition, penal provision, or illustration. [cite: 32][cite_start] Illustrations:

metadata.section_title: Definitions in the Code to be understood subject to exceptions.

page_content: inition, penal provision, or illustration. [cite: 32][cite_start] Illustrations: (a) The sections, in this Code, which contain definitions of offences, do not express that a child under seven years of age cannot commit such offences; but the definitions are to be understood subject to the general exception which provides that nothing shall be an offence which is done by a child under seven years of age. [cite: 34, 35]

metadata.section_title: Definitions in the Code to be understood subject to exceptions.

page_content: be an offence which is done by a child under seven years of age. [cite: 34, 35] (b) A, a police-officer, without warrant, apprehends Z, who has committed murder. [cite_start]Here A is not guilty of the offence of wrongful confinement; for he was bound by law to apprehend Z, and therefore the case falls within the general exception which provides that "nothing is an offence which is done by a person who is bound by law to do it". [cite: 36, 37, 38]

metadata.section_title: Definitions in the Code to be understood subject to exceptions.

page_content: Summary: Section 19: "Judge".

page_content: Section 19: "Judge".

metadata.section_title: "Judge".

page_content: 19 IPC 19 S. 19 Sec 19 Section 19

metadata.section_title: "Judge".

page_content: Section 19: "Judge". The word "Judge" denotes not only every person who is officially designated as a Judge, but also every person. who is empowered by law to give, in any legal proceeding, civil or criminal, a definitive judgment, or a judgment which, if not appealed against, would be definitive, or a judgment which, if confirmed by some other authority, would be definitive, or who is one of a body or persons, which body of persons is empowered by law to give such a judgment. [cite: 63, 64, 65][cite_start] Illustrations:

metadata.section_title: "Judge".

page_content: ed by law to give such a judgment. [cite: 63, 64, 65][cite_start] Illustrations: (a) A Collector exercising jurisdiction in a suit under Act 10 of 1859 is a Judge. [cite: 67][cite_start] (b) A Magistrate exercising jurisdiction in respect of a charge on which he has power to sentence to fine or imprisonment. with or without appear, is a Judge. [cite: 68, 69][cite_start] (c) A member of a panchayat which has power, under Regulation VII, 1816, of the Madras Code, to try and determine suits, is a Judge. [cite: 70][cite_start]

metadata.section_title: "Judge".

page_content: the Madras Code, to try and determine suits, is a Judge. [cite: 70][cite_start] (d) A Magistrate exercising jurisdiction in respect of a charge on which he has power only to commit for trial to another Court, is not a Judge. [cite: 71]

metadata.section_title: "Judge".

page_content: Summary: Section 20: "Court of Justice".

metadata.section_title: "Court of Justice".

page_content: Section 20: "Court of Justice".

metadata.section_title: "Court of Justice".

page_content: 20 IPC 20 S. 20 Sec 20 Section 20

metadata.section_title: "Court of Justice".

page_content: Section 20: "Court of Justice". The words "Court of Justice" denote a Judge who is empowered by law to act judicially alone, or a body of Judges which is empowered by law to act judicially as a body, when such Judge or body of Judges is acting judicially. [cite: 72][cite_start] Illustrations: A Panchayat acting under Regulation VII, 1816, of the Madras Code, having power to try and determine suits, is a Court of Justice. [cite: 74]

metadata.section_title: "Court of Justice".

page_content: 21 IPC 21 S. 21 Sec 21 Section 21

metadata.section_title: "Public servant".

page_content: Section 21: "Public servant". The words "public servant" denote a person falling under any of the descriptions hereinafter following, namely:- Second. [cite_start]Every Commissioned Officer in the Military, '[Naval or Air] Forces ⁷[⁸*** of India]; [cite: 80] [Third. [cite_start]Every Judge including any person empowered by law to discharge, whether by himself or as a member of any body of persons, any adjudicatory functions;] [cite: 81]

metadata.section_title: "Public servant".

page_content: f or as a member of any body of persons, any adjudicatory functions;] [cite: 81] Fourth. [cite_start]Every officer of a Court of Justice ¹⁰[(including a liquidator, receiver or commissioner)] whose duty it is, as such officer, to investigate or report on any matter of law or fact, or to make, authenticate, or keep any document, or to take charge or dispose of any property, or to execute any judicial process, or to administer any oath, or to interpret, or to preserve order in the Court, and every person specially authorised by a Court of Justice to perform any of such duties; [cite: 82]

metadata.section_title: "Public servant".

page_content: ially authorised by a Court of Justice to perform any of such duties; [cite: 82] Fifth. [cite_start]Every juryman, assessor, or member of a panchayat assisting a Court of Justice or public servant; [cite: 83] Sixth. [cite_start]Every arbitrator or other person to whom any cause or matter has been referred for decision or report by any Court of Justice, or by any other competent public authority; [cite: 84] Seventh. [cite_start]Every person who holds any office by virtue of which he is empowered to place or keep any person in confinement; [cite: 97]

metadata.section_title: "Public servant".

page_content: of which he is empowered to place or keep any person in confinement; [cite: 97] Eighth. [cite_start]Every officer of ¹[the Government] whose duty it is, as such officer, to prevent offences, to give information of offences, to bring offenders to justice, or to protect the public health, safety or convenience; [cite: 98]

metadata.section_title: "Public servant".

page_content: s to justice, or to protect the public health, safety or convenience; [cite: 98] Ninth. [cite_start]Every officer whose duty it is as such officer, to take, receive, keep or expend any property on behalf of ¹[the Government], or to make any survey, assessment or contract on behalf of ¹[the Government], or to execute any revenue-process, or to investigate, or to report, on any matter affecting the pecuniary interests of ¹[the Government], or to make, authenticate or keep any document relating to the pecuniary interests of ¹[the Government], or to prevent the infraction of any law for the protection of the pecuniary interests of ¹[the Government] ²***; [cite: 99]

metadata.section_title: "Public servant".

page_content: the protection of the pecuniary interests of ¹[the Government] ²***; [cite: 99] Tenth. [cite_start]Every officer whose duty it is, as such officer, to take, receive, keep or expend any property, to make any survey or assessment or to levy any rate or tax for any secular common purpose of any village, town or district, or to make, authenticate or keep any document for the ascertaining of the rights of the people of any village, town or district; [cite: 100]

metadata.section_title: "Public servant".

page_content: aining of the rights of the people of any village, town or district; [cite: 100] ³[Eleventh. [cite_start]Every person who holds any office in virtue of which he is empowered to prepare, publish, maintain or revise an electoral roll or to conduct an election or part of an election;] [cite: 101] ⁴[Twelfth. [cite_start]Every person- (a) in the service or pay of the Government or remunerated by fees or commission for the performance of any public duty by the Government; [cite: 103][cite_start]

metadata.section_title: "Public servant".

page_content: or the performance of any public duty by the Government; [cite: 103][cite_start] (b) in the service or pay of a local authority, a corporation established by or under a Central, Provincial or State Act or a Government company as defined in section 617 of the Companies Act, 1956 (1 of 1956).] [cite: 104][cite_start] Explanation 1.-Persons falling under any of the above descriptions are public servants, whether appointed by the Government or not. [cite: 107][cite_start]

metadata.section_title: "Public servant".

page_content: ic servants, whether appointed by the Government or not. [cite: 107][cite_start] Explanation 2.-Wherever the words "public servant" occur, they shall be understood of every person who is in actual possession of the situation of a public servant, whatever legal defect there may be in his right to hold that situation. [cite: 108][cite_start]

metadata.section_title: "Public servant".

page_content: defect there may be in his right to hold that situation. [cite: 108][cite_start] ⁵[Explanation 3. The word "election" denotes an election for the purpose of selecting members of any legislative, municipal or other public authority, of whatever character, the method of selection to which is by, or under, any law prescribed as by election.] [cite: 109][cite_start] Illustrations: A Municipal Commissioner is a public servant. [cite: 105][cite_start]

metadata.section_title: "Public servant".

metadata.section_title: "Movable property".

page_content: Section 22: "Movable property". The words "movable property" are intended to include corporeal property of every description, except land and things attached to the earth or permanently fastened to anything which is attached to the earth. [cite: 130]

metadata.section_title: "Movable property".

page_content: Summary: Section 23: "Wrongful gain".

metadata.section_title: "Wrongful gain".

page_content: Section 23: "Wrongful gain".

metadata.section_title: "Wrongful gain".

page_content: 23 IPC 23 S. 23 Sec 23 Section 23

metadata.section_title: "Wrongful gain".

page_content: Section 23: "Wrongful gain". "Wrongful gain" is gain by unlawful means of property to which the person gaining is not legally entitled. "Wrongful loss".- "Wrongful loss" is the loss by unlawful means of property to which the person losing it is legally entitled. Gaining wrongfully/Losing wrongfully. A person is said to gain wrongfully when such person retains wrongfully, as well as when such person acquires wrongfully. [cite_start]A person is said to lose wrongfully when such person is wrongfully kept out of any property, as well as when such person is wrongfully deprived of property. [cite: 131, 132, 133, 134]

metadata.section_title: "Wrongful gain".

page_content: Summary: Section 27: "Property in possession of wife, clerk or servant".

page_content: 27 IPC 27 S. 27 Sec 27 Section 27

metadata.section_title: "Property in possession of wife, clerk or servant".

page_content: Section 27: "Property in possession of wife, clerk or servant". When property is in the possession of a person's wife, clerk or servant, on account of that person, it is in that person's possession within the meaning of this Code. Explanation. [cite_start]A person employed temporarily or on a particular occasion in the capacity of a clerk, or servant, is a clerk or servant within the meaning of this section. [cite: 138, 139]

metadata.section_title: "Property in possession of wife, clerk or servant".

page_content: Summary: Section 28: "Counterfeit".

metadata.section_title: "Counterfeit".

page_content: Section 28: "Counterfeit".

metadata.section_title: "Counterfeit".

page_content: 28 IPC 28 S. 28 Sec 28 Section 28

metadata.section_title: "Counterfeit".

page_content: Section 28: "Counterfeit". A person is said to "counterfeit" who causes one thing to resemble another thing, intending by means of that resemblance to practise deception, or knowing it to be likely that deception will thereby be practised. ¹[Explanation 1. It is not essential to counterfeiting that the imitation should be exact. [cite_start]Explanation 2.-When a person causes one thing to resemble another thing, and the resemblance is such that a person might be deceived thereby, it shall be presumed, until the contrary is proved, that the person so causing the one thing to resemble the other thing intended by means of that resemblance to practise deception or knew it to be likely that deception would thereby be practised.] [cite: 140, 141, 142]

metadata.section_title: "Counterfeit".

page_content: Summary: Section 29: "Document".

metadata.section_title: "Document".

page_content: Section 29: "Document".

metadata.section_title: "Document".

page_content: 29 IPC 29 S. 29 Sec 29 Section 29

metadata.section_title: "Document".

page_content: Section 29: "Document". The word "document" denotes any matter expressed or described upon any substance by means of letters, figures or marks, or by more than one of those means, intended to be used, or which may be used, as evidence of that matter. Explanation 1. It is immaterial by what means or upon what substance the letters, figures or marks are formed, or whether the evidence is intended for, or may be used in, a Court of Justice, or not. [cite_start]Explanation 2.-Whatever is expressed by means of letters, figures or marks as explained by mercantile or other usage, shall be deemed to be expressed by such letters, figures or marks within the meaning of this section, although the same may not be actually expressed. [cite: 143, 144, 151][cite_start]

metadata.section_title: "Document".

page_content: though the same may not be actually expressed. [cite: 143, 144, 151][cite_start] Illustrations:

metadata.section_title: "Document".

page_content: may not be actually expressed. [cite: 143, 144, 151][cite_start] Illustrations: A writing expressing the terms of a contract, which may be used as evidence of the contract, is a document. [cite: 146][cite_start] A cheque upon a banker is a document. [cite: 147][cite_start] A power-of-attorney is a document. [cite: 148][cite_start] A map or plan which is intended to be used or which may be used as evidence, is a document. [cite: 149][cite_start] A writing containing directions or instructions is a document. [cite: 150] A writes his name on the back of a bill of exchange payable to his order. The meaning of the endorsement, as explained by mercantile usage, is that the bill is to be paid to the holder. [cite_start]The endorsement is a document, and must be construed in the same manner as if the words "pay to the holder" or words to that effect had been written over the signature. [cite: 153, 154, 155]

metadata.section_title: "Document".

page_content: Section 29A: "Electronic record". The words "electronic record" shall have the meaning assigned to them in clause (t) of sub-section (1) of section 2 of the Information Technology Act, 2000 (21 of 2000). [cite: 156]

metadata.section_title: "Electronic record".

page_content: Summary: Section 30: "Valuable security".

metadata.section_title: "Valuable security".

page_content: Section 30: "Valuable security".

metadata.section_title: "Valuable security".

page_content: 30 IPC 30 S. 30 Sec 30 Section 30

metadata.section_title: "Valuable security".

page_content: Section 30: "Valuable security". The words "valuable security" denote a document which is, or purports to be, a document whereby any legal right is created, extended, transferred, restricted, extinguished or released, or whereby any person acknowledges that he lies under legal liability, or has not a certain legal right. [cite: 160] Illustrations: A writes his name on the back of a bill of exchange. [cite_start]As the effect of this endorsement is to transfer the right to the bill to any person who may become the unlawful holder of it, the endorsement is a "valuable security". [cite: 162, 163]

metadata.section_title: "Valuable security".

metadata.section_title: "A will".

page_content: Section 31: "A will".

metadata.section_title: "A will".

page_content: 31 IPC 31 S. 31 Sec 31 Section 31

page_content: Section 31: "A will". The words "a will" denote any testamentary document. [cite: 164]

page_content: Section 32: Words referring to acts include illegal omissions. In every part of this Code, except where a contrary intention appears from the context, words which refer to acts done extend also to illegal omissions. [cite: 165]

page_content: Section 33: "Act". [cite_start]"Omission". The word "act" denotes as well as series of acts as a single act: the word "omission" denotes as well a series of omissions as a single omission. [cite: 166]

metadata.section_title: Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention.

page_content: Section 34: Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention. When a criminal act is done by several persons in furtherance of the common intention of all, each of such persons is liable for that act in the same manner as if it were done by him alone. [cite: 168]

metadata.section_title: Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention.

page_content: Summary: Section 35: When such an act is criminal by reason of its being done with a criminal knowledge or intention.

metadata.section_title: When such an act is criminal by reason of its being done with a criminal knowledge or intention.

metadata.section_title: When such an act is criminal by reason of its being done with a criminal knowledge or intention.

page_content: 35 IPC 35 S. 35 Sec 35 Section 35

metadata.section_title: When such an act is criminal by reason of its being done with a criminal knowledge or intention.

page_content: Section 35: When such an act is criminal by reason of its being done with a criminal knowledge or intention. Whenever an act, which is criminal only by reason of its being done with a criminal knowledge or intention, is done by several persons, each of such persons who joins in the act with such knowledge or intention is liable for the act in the same manner as if the act were done by him alone with that knowledge or intention. [cite: 170]

metadata.section_title: When such an act is criminal by reason of its being done with a criminal knowledge or intention.

page_content: Summary: Section 36: Effect caused partly by act and partly by omission.

metadata.section_title: Effect caused partly by act and partly by omission.

page_content: Section 36: Effect caused partly by act and partly by omission.

metadata.section_title: Effect caused partly by act and partly by omission.

page_content: 36 IPC 36 S. 36 Sec 36 Section 36

metadata.section_title: Effect caused partly by act and partly by omission.

page_content: Section 36: Effect caused partly by act and partly by omission. Wherever the causing of a certain effect, or an attempt to cause that effect, by an act or by an omission, is an offence, it is to be understood that the causing of that effect partly by an act and partly by an omission is the same offence. [cite: 171][cite_start] Illustrations: A intentionally causes Z's death, partly by illegally omitting to give Z food, and party by beating Z. A has committed murder. [cite: 173]

metadata.section_title: Effect caused partly by act and partly by omission.

page_content: Summary: Section 37: Co-operation by doing one of several acts constituting an offence.

metadata.section_title: Co-operation by doing one of several acts constituting an offence.

page_content: Section 37: Co-operation by doing one of several acts constituting an offence.

metadata.section_title: Co-operation by doing one of several acts constituting an offence.

page_content: 37 IPC 37 S. 37 Sec 37 Section 37

metadata.section_title: Co-operation by doing one of several acts constituting an offence.

page_content: Section 37: Co-operation by doing one of several acts constituting an offence. When an offence is committed by means of several acts, whoever intentionally co-operates in the commission of that offence by doing any one of those acts, either singly or jointly with any other person, commits that offence. [cite: 175] Illustrations:

metadata.section_title: Co-operation by doing one of several acts constituting an offence.

page_content: jointly with any other person, commits that offence. [cite: 175] Illustrations: (a) A and B agree to murder Z by severally and at different times giving him small doses of poison. A and B administer the poison according to the agreement with intent to murder Z. Z dies from the effects the several doses of poison so administered to him. [cite_start]Here A and B intentionally co-operate in the commission of murder and as each of them does an act by which the death is caused, they are both guilty of the offence though their acts are separate. [cite: 177, 178, 179]

metadata.section_title: Co-operation by doing one of several acts constituting an offence.

page_content: both guilty of the offence though their acts are separate. [cite: 177, 178, 179] (b) A and B are joint jailors, and as such have the charge of Z, a prisoner, alternatively for six hours at a time. A and B, intending to cause Z's death, knowingly co-operate in causing that effect by illegally omitting, each during the time of his attendance, to furnish Z with food supplied to them for that purpose. Z dies of hunger. [cite_start]Both A and B, are guilty of the murder of Z. [cite: 180, 181, 182, 183]

metadata.section_title: Co-operation by doing one of several acts constituting an offence.

page_content: te_start]Both A and B, are guilty of the murder of Z. [cite: 180, 181, 182, 183] (c) A, a jailor, has the charge of Z. a prisoner. A, intending to cause Z's death, illegally omits to supply Z with food; in consequence of which Z is much reduced in strength, but the starvation is not sufficient to cause his death. A is dismissed from his office, and B succeeds him. B, without collusion or co-operation with A, illegally omits to supply Z with food, knowing that he is likely thereby to cause Z's death. Z dies of hunger. [cite_start]B is guilty of murder, but, as A did not co-operate with B. A is guilty only of an attempt to commit murder. [cite: 184, 185, 186, 187, 188, 189]

metadata.section_title: Co-operation by doing one of several acts constituting an offence.

page_content: Summary: Section 38: Persons concerned in criminal act may be guilty of different offences.

metadata.section_title: Persons concerned in criminal act may be guilty of different offences.

page_content: Section 38: Persons concerned in criminal act may be guilty of different offences.

metadata.section_title: Persons concerned in criminal act may be guilty of different offences.

page_content: 38 IPC 38 S. 38 Sec 38 Section 38

metadata.section_title: Persons concerned in criminal act may be guilty of different offences.

page_content: Section 38: Persons concerned in criminal act may be guilty of different offences. Where several persons are engaged or concerned in the commission of a criminal act, they may be guilty of different offences by means of that act. [cite: 191] Illustrations:

metadata.section_title: Persons concerned in criminal act may be guilty of different offences.

page_content: be guilty of different offences by means of that act. [cite: 191] Illustrations: A attacks Z under such circumstances of grave provocation that his killing of Z would be only culpable homicide not amounting to murder. [cite_start]B, having ill-will towards Z and intending to kill him, and not having been subject to the provocation, assists A in killing Z. Here, though A and B are both engaged in causing Z's death, B is guilty of murder, and A is guilty only of culpable homicide. [cite: 193, 194]

metadata.section_title: Persons concerned in criminal act may be guilty of different offences.

page_content: Summary: Section 39: "Voluntarily".

metadata.section_title: "Voluntarily".

page_content: Section 39: "Voluntarily".

metadata.section_title: "Voluntarily".

page_content: 39 IPC 39 S. 39 Sec 39 Section 39

metadata.section_title: "Voluntarily".

page_content: Section 39: "Voluntarily". A person is said to cause an effect "voluntarily" when he causes it by means whereby he intended to cause it, or by means which, at the time of employing those means, he knew or had reason to believe to be likely to cause it. [cite: 197] Illustrations:

metadata.section_title: "Voluntarily".

page_content: ew or had reason to believe to be likely to cause it. [cite: 197] Illustrations: A sets fire, by night, to an inhabited house in a large town, for the purpose of facilitating a robbery and thus causes the death of a person. [cite_start]Here, A may not have intended to cause death, and may even be sorry that death has been caused by his act; yet, if he knew that he was likely to cause death, he has caused death voluntarily. [cite: 199, 200, 201]

metadata.section_title: "Voluntarily".

page_content: Section 40: "Offence". Except in the [Chapters] and sections mentioned in clauses 2 and 3 of this section, the word "offence" denotes a thing made punishable by this Code. In Chapter IV, [Chapter VA] and in the following sections, namely, sections [64, 65, 66, [67], 71], 109, 110, 112, 114, 115, 116, 117, 118, 119 and 120] 187, 194, 195, 203, 211, 213, 214, 221, 222, 223, 224, 225, 327, 328, 329, 330, 331, 347, 348, 388, 389 and 445, the word "offence" denotes a thing punishable under this Code, or under any special or local law as hereinafter defined. [cite_start]And in sections 141, 176, 177, 201, 202, 212, 216 and 441, the word "offence" has the same meaning when the thing punishable under the special or local law is punishable under such law with imprisonment for a term of six months or upwards, whether with or without fine. [cite: 202, 203, 204]

page_content: Section 52A: "Harbour". Except in section 157, and in section 130 in the case in which the harbour is given by the wife or husband of the person harboured, the word "harbour" includes the supplying a person with shelter, food, drink, money, clothes, arms, ammunition or means of conveyance, or the assisting a person by any means, whether of the same kind as those enumerated in this section or not, to evade apprehension. [cite: 229]

metadata.section_title: Punishments.

page_content: Section 53: Punishments. The punishments to which offenders are liable under the provisions of this Code are- First, Death; [cite: 233] [Secondly. [cite_start]Imprisonment for life;] [cite: 234] Fourthly. [cite_start]Imprisonment, which is of two descriptions, namely:- (1) Rigorous, that is, with hard labour; [cite: 239][cite_start] (2) Simple; [cite: 240] Fifthly. [cite_start]Forfeiture of property; [cite: 241] Sixthly. [cite_start]Fine. [cite: 242]

metadata.section_title: Punishments.

page_content: Summary: Section 53A: Construction of reference to transportation.

metadata.section_title: Construction of reference to transportation.

page_content: 53 A 53-A 53A IPC 53 A IPC 53-A IPC 53A S. 53 A S. 53-A S. 53A Sec 53 A Sec 53-A Sec 53A Section 53 A Section 53-A Section 53A

metadata.section_title: Construction of reference to transportation.

page_content: Section 53A: Construction of reference to transportation. (1) Subject to the provisions of sub-section (2) and sub-section (3), any reference to "transportation for life" in any other law for the time being in force or in any instrument or order having effect by virtue of any such law or of any enactment repealed shall be construed as a reference to "imprisonment for life". [cite: 245][cite_start]

metadata.section_title: Construction of reference to transportation.

page_content: be construed as a reference to "imprisonment for life". [cite: 245][cite_start] (2) In every case in which a sentence of transportation for a term has been passed before the commencement of the Code of Criminal Procedure (Amendment) Act, [1955] (26 of 1955), the offender shall be dealt with in the same manner as if sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for the same term. [cite: 246][cite_start]

metadata.section_title: Construction of reference to transportation.

page_content: if sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for the same term. [cite: 246][cite_start] (3) Any reference to transportation for a term or to transportation for any shorter term (by whatever name called) in any other law for the time being in force shall be deemed to have been omitted. [cite: 247][cite_start] (4) Any reference to "transportation" in any other law for the time being in force shall,- (a) if the expression means transportation for life, be construed as a reference to imprisonment for life; [cite: 250][cite_start] e, be construed as a reference to imprisonment for life; [cite: 250][cite_start] (b) if the expression means transportation for any shorter term, be deemed to have been omitted. [cite: 251]

metadata.section_title: Construction of reference to transportation.

page_content: Section 54: Commutation of sentence of death. In every case in which sentence of death shall have been passed, [the appropriate Government] may, without the consent of the offender, commute the punishment for any other punishment provided by this Code. [cite: 252]

page_content: Section 55: Commutation of sentence of imprisonment for life. In every case in which sentence of [imprisonment] for life shall have been passed, [the appropriate Government] may, without the consent of the offender, commute the punishment for imprisonment of either description for a term not exceeding fourteen years. [cite: 253, 265]

metadata.section_title: Definition of "appropriate Government".

page_content: Section 55A: Definition of "appropriate Government". In sections fifty-four and fifty-five the expression "appropriate Government" means,- (a) in cases where the sentence is a sentence of death or is for an offence against any law relating to a matter to which the executive power of the Union extends, the Central Government; and [cite: 267, 268][cite_start]

metadata.section_title: Definition of "appropriate Government".

page_content: r of the Union extends, the Central Government; and [cite: 267, 268][cite_start] (b) in cases where the sentence (whether of death or not) is for an offence against any law relating to a matter to which the executive power of the State extends, the Government of the State within which the offender is sentenced. [cite: 269]

metadata.section_title: Definition of "appropriate Government".

page_content: Section 60: Sentence may be (in certain cases of imprisonment) wholly or partly rigorous or simple. In every case in which an offender is punishable with imprisonment which may be of either description, it shall be competent to the Court which sentences such offender to direct in the sentence that such imprisonment shall be wholly rigorous, or that such imprisonment shall be wholly simple, or that any part of such imprisonment shall be rigorous and the rest simple. [cite: 275]

page_content: Section 63: Amount of fine. Where no sum is expressed to which a fine may extend, the amount of fine to which the offender is liable is unlimited, but shall not be excessive. [cite: 278]

metadata.section_title: Amount of fine.

page_content: Summary: Section 64: Sentence of imprisonment for non-payment of fine.

metadata.section_title: Sentence of imprisonment for non-payment of fine.

page_content: Section 64: Sentence of imprisonment for non-payment of fine.

page_content: 64 IPC 64 S. 64 Sec 64 Section 64

metadata.section_title: Sentence of imprisonment for non-payment of fine.

page_content: Section 64: Sentence of imprisonment for non-payment of fine. ³[In every case of an offence punishable with imprisonment as well as fine, in which the offender is sentenced to a fine, whether with or without imprisonment, and in every case of an offence punishable ⁴[with imprisonment or fine, or] with fine only, in which the offender is sentenced to a fine.] it shall be competent to the Court which sentences such offender to direct by the sentence that, in default of payment of the fine, the offender shall suffer imprisonment for a certain term, which imprisonment shall be in excess of any other imprisonment to which he may have been sentenced or to which he may be liable under a commutation of a sentence. [cite: 279, 280, 281]

metadata.section_title: Sentence of imprisonment for non-payment of fine.

metadata.section_title: Limit to imprisonment for non-payment of fine, when imprisonment and fine awardable.

page_content: Section 65: Limit to imprisonment for non-payment of fine, when imprisonment and fine awardable. The term for which the Court directs the offender to be imprisoned in default of payment of a fine shall not exceed one-fourth of the term of imprisonment which is the maximum fixed for the offence, if the offence be punishable with imprisonment as well as fine. [cite: 282]

metadata.section_title: Limit to imprisonment for non-payment of fine, when imprisonment and fine awardable.

metadata.section_title: Description of imprisonment for non-payment of fine.

page_content: Section 66: Description of imprisonment for non-payment of fine. The imprisonment which the Court imposes in default of payment of a fine may be of any description to which the offender might have been sentenced for the offence. [cite: 283]

metadata.section_title: Description of imprisonment for non-payment of fine.

page_content: Summary: Section 67: Imprisonment for non-payment of fine, when offence punishable with fine only.

metadata.section_title: Imprisonment for non-payment of fine, when offence punishable with fine only.

page_content: Section 67: Imprisonment for non-payment of fine, when offence punishable with fine only.

metadata.section_title: Imprisonment for non-payment of fine, when offence punishable with fine only.

page_content: 67 IPC 67 S. 67 Sec 67 Section 67

metadata.section_title: Imprisonment for non-payment of fine, when offence punishable with fine only.

page_content: Section 67: Imprisonment for non-payment of fine, when offence punishable with fine only. If the offence be punishable with fine only. [cite_start]¹[the imprisonment which the Court imposes in default of payment of the fine shall be simple, and] the term for which the Court directs the offender to be imprisoned, in default of payment of fine, shall not exceed the following scale, that is to say, for any term not exceeding two months when the amount of the fine shall not exceed fifty rupees, and for any term not exceeding four months when the amount shall not exceed one hundred rupees, and for any term not exceeding six months in any other case. [cite: 289, 290]

metadata.section_title: Imprisonment for non-payment of fine, when offence punishable with fine only.

page_content: Summary: Section 68: Imprisonment to terminate on payment of fine.

metadata.section_title: Imprisonment to terminate on payment of fine.

page_content: 68 IPC 68 S. 68 Sec 68 Section 68

metadata.section_title: Imprisonment to terminate on payment of fine.

page_content: Section 68: Imprisonment to terminate on payment of fine. The imprisonment which is imposed in default of payment of a fine shall terminate whenever that fine is either paid or levied by process of law. [cite: 291]

metadata.section_title: Imprisonment to terminate on payment of fine.

page_content: Summary: Section 69: Termination of imprisonment on payment of proportional part of fine.

metadata.section_title: Termination of imprisonment on payment of proportional part of fine.

page_content: Section 69: Termination of imprisonment on payment of proportional part of fine.

metadata.section_title: Termination of imprisonment on payment of proportional part of fine.

page_content: 69 IPC 69 S. 69 Sec 69 Section 69

metadata.section_title: Termination of imprisonment on payment of proportional part of fine.

page_content: Section 69: Termination of imprisonment on payment of proportional part of fine. If, before the expiration of the term of imprisonment fixed in default of payment, such a proportion of the fine be paid or levied that the term of imprisonment suffered in default of payment is not less than proportional to the part of the fine still unpaid, the imprisonment shall terminate. [cite: 293] Illustrations:

metadata.section_title: Termination of imprisonment on payment of proportional part of fine.

page_content: fine still unpaid, the imprisonment shall terminate. [cite: 293] Illustrations: A is sentenced to a fine of one hundred rupees and to four months' imprisonment in default of payment. Here, if seventy-five rupees of the fine be paid or levied before the expiration of one month of the imprisonment, A will be discharged as soon as the first month has expired. If seventy-five rupees be paid or levied at the time of the expiration of the first month, or at any later time while A continues in imprisonment, A will be immediately discharged. If fifty rupees of the fine be paid or levied before the expiration of two months of the imprisonment. A will be discharged as soon as the two months are completed. [cite_start]If fifty rupees be paid or levied at the time of the expiration of those two months, or at any later time while A continues in imprisonment, A will be immediately discharged. [cite: 295, 296, 297, 298, 299, 300]

metadata.section_title: Termination of imprisonment on payment of proportional part of fine.

page_content: Summary: Section 70: Fine leviable within six years, or during imprisonment.

metadata.section_title: Fine leviable within six years, or during imprisonment. [cite_start]Death not to discharge property from liability.

page_content: Section 70: Fine leviable within six years, or during imprisonment. [cite_start]Death not to discharge property from liability.

metadata.section_title: Fine leviable within six years, or during imprisonment. [cite_start]Death not to discharge property from liability.

page_content: 70 IPC 70 S. 70 Sec 70 Section 70

metadata.section_title: Fine leviable within six years, or during imprisonment. [cite_start]Death not to discharge property from liability.

page_content: Section 70: Fine leviable within six years, or during imprisonment. [cite_start]Death not to discharge property from liability. The fine, or any part thereof which remains unpaid, may be levied at any time within six years after the passing of the sentence, and if, under the sentence, the offender be liable to imprisonment for a longer period than six years, then at any time previous to the expiration of that period; and the death of the offender does not discharge from the liability any property which would, after his death, be legally liable for his debts. [cite: 302, 303]

metadata.section_title: Fine leviable within six years, or during imprisonment. [cite_start]Death not to discharge property from liability.

page_content: Summary: Section 71: Limit of punishment of offence made up of several offences.

metadata.section_title: Limit of punishment of offence made up of several offences.

page_content: Section 71: Limit of punishment of offence made up of several offences.

metadata.section_title: Limit of punishment of offence made up of several offences.

page_content: 71 IPC 71 S. 71 Sec 71 Section 71

metadata.section_title: Limit of punishment of offence made up of several offences.

page_content: Section 71: Limit of punishment of offence made up of several offences. Where anything which is an offence is made up of parts, any of which parts is itself an offence, the offender shall not be punished with the punishment of more than one of such his offences, unless it be so expressly provided. [cite: 305][cite_start] [Where anything is an offence falling within two or more separate definitions of any law in force for the time being by which offences are defined or punished, or where several acts, of which one or more than one would by itself or themselves constitute an offence, constitute, when combined, a different offence, the offender shall not be punished with a more severe punishment than the Court which tries him could award for any one of such offences]. [cite: 306, 307, 308]

metadata.section_title: Limit of punishment of offence made up of several offences.

page_content: which tries him could award for any one of such offences]. [cite: 306, 307, 308] Illustrations: (a) A gives Z fifty strokes with a stick. Here A may have committed the offence of voluntarily causing hurt to Z by the whole beating, and also by each of the blows which make up the whole beating. If A were liable to punishment for every blow, he might be imprisoned for fifty years, one for each blow. [cite_start]But he is liable only to one punishment for the whole beating. [cite: 310, 311, 312][cite_start]

metadata.section_title: Limit of punishment of offence made up of several offences.

page_content: only to one punishment for the whole beating. [cite: 310, 311, 312][cite_start] (b) But, if, while A is beating Z, Y interferes, and A intentionally strikes Y, here, as the blow given to Y is no part of the act whereby A voluntarily causes hurt to Z, A is liable to one punishment for voluntarily causing hurt to Z, and to another for the blow given to Y. [cite: 313]

metadata.section_title: Limit of punishment of offence made up of several offences.

page_content: Summary: Section 72: Punishment of person guilty of one of several offences, the judgment stating that it is doubtful of which.

metadata.section_title: Punishment of person guilty of one of several offences, the judgment stating that it is doubtful of which.

page_content: Section 72: Punishment of person guilty of one of several offences, the judgment stating that it is doubtful of which.

metadata.section_title: Punishment of person guilty of one of several offences, the judgment stating that it is doubtful of which.

page_content: Section 72: Punishment of person guilty of one of several offences, the judgment stating that it is doubtful of which. In all cases in which judgment is given that a person is guilty of one of several offences specified in the judgment, but that it is doubtful of which of these offences he is guilty, the offender shall be punished for the offence for which the lowest punishment is provided if the same punishment is not provided for all. [cite: 315]

metadata.section_title: Punishment of person guilty of one of several offences, the judgment stating that it is doubtful of which.

page_content: Summary: Section 73: Solitary confinement.

metadata.section_title: Solitary confinement.

page_content: Section 73: Solitary confinement.

metadata.section_title: Solitary confinement.

page_content: 73 IPC 73 S. 73 Sec 73 Section 73

metadata.section_title: Solitary confinement.

page_content: Section 73: Solitary confinement. Whenever any person is convicted of an offence for which under this Code the Court has power to sentence him to rigorous imprisonment, the Court may, by its sentence, order that the offender shall be kept in solitary confinement for any portion or portions of the imprisonment to which he is sentenced, not exceeding three months in the whole, according to the following scale, that is to say- a time not exceeding one month if the term of imprisonment shall not exceed six months; [cite: 319][cite_start] a time not exceeding two months if the term of imprisonment shall exceed six months and [shall not exceed one] year; [cite: 320][cite_start] a time not exceeding three months if the term of imprisonment shall exceed one year. [cite: 321]

metadata.section_title: Solitary confinement.

page_content: Summary: Section 74: Limit of solitary confinement.

metadata.section_title: Limit of solitary confinement.

page_content: Section 74: Limit of solitary confinement.

metadata.section_title: Limit of solitary confinement.

page_content: 74 IPC 74 S. 74 Sec 74 Section 74

metadata.section_title: Limit of solitary confinement.

page_content: Section 74: Limit of solitary confinement. In executing a sentence of solitary confinement, such confinement shall in no case exceed fourteen days at a time, with intervals between the periods of solitary confinement of not less duration than such periods, and when the imprisonment awarded shall exceed three months, the solitary confinement shall not exceed seven days in any one month of the whole imprisonment awarded, with intervals between the periods of solitary confinement of not less duration than such periods. [cite: 322]

metadata.section_title: Limit of solitary confinement.

page_content: Summary: Section 75: Enhanced punishment for certain offences under Chapter XII or Chapter XVII after previous conviction.

metadata.section_title: Enhanced punishment for certain offences under Chapter XII or Chapter XVII after previous conviction.

page_content: 75 IPC 75 S. 75 Sec 75 Section 75

metadata.section_title: Enhanced punishment for certain offences under Chapter XII or Chapter XVII after previous conviction.

page_content: Section 75: Enhanced punishment for certain offences under Chapter XII or Chapter XVII after previous conviction. Whoever, having been convicted,- (a) by a Court in [India], of an offence punishable under Chapter XII or Chapter XVII of this Code with imprisonment of either description for a term of three years or upwards, ⁴*** [cite: 324][cite_start]

metadata.section_title: Enhanced punishment for certain offences under Chapter XII or Chapter XVII after previous conviction.

page_content: r description for a term of three years or upwards, ⁴*** [cite: 324][cite_start] shall be guilty of any offence punishable under either of those Chapters with like imprisonment for the like term, shall be subject for every such subsequent offence to [imprisonment for life], or to imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years. [cite: 330]

metadata.section_title: Enhanced punishment for certain offences under Chapter XII or Chapter XVII after previous conviction.

page_content: Summary: Section 76: Act done by a person bound, or by mistake of fact believing himself bound, by law.

metadata.section_title: Act done by a person bound, or by mistake of fact believing himself bound, by law.

page_content: Section 76: Act done by a person bound, or by mistake of fact believing himself bound, by law.

metadata.section_title: Act done by a person bound, or by mistake of fact believing himself bound, by law.

page_content: 76 IPC 76 S. 76 Sec 76 Section 76

metadata.section_title: Act done by a person bound, or by mistake of fact believing himself bound, by law.

page_content: Section 76: Act done by a person bound, or by mistake of fact believing himself bound, by law. Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who is, or who by reason of a mistake of fact and not by reason of a mistake of law in good faith believes himself to be, bound by law to do it. [cite: 333] Illustrations: (a) A, a soldier, fires on a mob by the order of his superior officer, in conformity with the commands of the law. [cite_start]A has committed no offence. [cite: 335, 336][cite_start]

metadata.section_title: Act done by a person bound, or by mistake of fact believing himself bound, by law.

page_content: of the law. [cite_start]A has committed no offence. [cite: 335, 336][cite_start] (b) A, an officer of a Court of Justice, being ordered by that Court to arrest Y and, after due enquiry, believing Z to be Y, arrests Z. A has committed no offence. [cite: 337]

metadata.section_title: Act done by a person bound, or by mistake of fact believing himself bound, by law.

metadata.section_title: Act of Judge when acting judicially.

page_content: Section 77: Act of Judge when acting judicially. Nothing is an offence which is done by a Judge when acting judicially in the exercise of any power which is, or which in good faith he believes to be, given to him by law. [cite: 338]

metadata.section_title: Act of Judge when acting judicially.

page_content: Summary: Section 78: Act done pursuant to the judgment or order of Court.

metadata.section_title: Act done pursuant to the judgment or order of Court.

page_content: Section 78: Act done pursuant to the judgment or order of Court.

page_content: 78 IPC 78 S. 78 Sec 78 Section 78

metadata.section_title: Act done pursuant to the judgment or order of Court.

page_content: Section 78: Act done pursuant to the judgment or order of Court. Nothing which is done in pursuance of, or which is warranted by the judgment or order of, a Court of Justice, if done whilst such judgment or order remains in force, is an offence, notwithstanding the Court may have had no jurisdiction to pass such judgment or order, provided the person doing the act in good faith believes that the Court had such jurisdiction. [cite: 339]

metadata.section_title: Act done pursuant to the judgment or order of Court.

page_content: Summary: Section 79: Act done by a person justified, or by mistake of fact believing himself justified, by law.

metadata.section_title: Act done by a person justified, or by mistake of fact believing himself justified, by law.

page_content: Section 79: Act done by a person justified, or by mistake of fact believing himself justified, by law.

metadata.section_title: Act done by a person justified, or by mistake of fact believing himself justified, by law.

page_content: 79 IPC 79 S. 79 Sec 79 Section 79

metadata.section_title: Act done by a person justified, or by mistake of fact believing himself justified, by law.

page_content: Section 79: Act done by a person justified, or by mistake of fact believing himself justified, by law. Nothing is an offence which is done by any person who is justified by law, or who by reason of a mistake of fact and not by reason of a mistake of law in good faith, believes himself to be justified by law, in doing it. [cite: 340, 349] Illustrations:

metadata.section_title: Act done by a person justified, or by mistake of fact believing himself justified, by law.

page_content: ves himself to be justified by law, in doing it. [cite: 340, 349] Illustrations: A sees Z commit what appears to A to be a murder. A, in the exercise, to the best of his judgment exerted in good faith, of the power which the law gives to all persons of apprehending murderers in the fact, seizes Z., in order to bring Z before the proper authorities. [cite_start]A has committed no offence, though it may turn out that Z was acting in self-defence. [cite: 351, 352, 353]

metadata.section_title: Act done by a person justified, or by mistake of fact believing himself justified, by law.

page_content: Summary: Section 80: Accident in doing a lawful act.

metadata.section_title: Accident in doing a lawful act.

page_content: Section 80: Accident in doing a lawful act.

metadata.section_title: Accident in doing a lawful act.

page_content: 80 IPC 80 S. 80 Sec 80 Section 80

metadata.section_title: Accident in doing a lawful act.

page_content: Section 80: Accident in doing a lawful act. Nothing is an offence which is done by accident or misfortune, and without any criminal intention or knowledge in the doing of a lawful act in a lawful manner by lawful means and with proper care and caution. [cite: 354] Illustrations: A is at work with a hatchet; the head flies off and kills a man who is standing by. [cite_start]Here, if there was no want of proper caution on the part of A, his act is excusable and not an offence. [cite: 356, 357]

metadata.section_title: Accident in doing a lawful act.

page_content: Summary: Section 81: Act likely to cause harm, but done without criminal intent, and to prevent other harm.

metadata.section_title: Act likely to cause harm, but done without criminal intent, and to prevent other harm.

page_content: Section 81: Act likely to cause harm, but done without criminal intent, and to prevent other harm.

metadata.section_title: Act likely to cause harm, but done without criminal intent, and to prevent other harm.

page_content: 81 IPC 81 S. 81 Sec 81 Section 81

metadata.section_title: Act likely to cause harm, but done without criminal intent, and to prevent other harm.

page_content: Section 81: Act likely to cause harm, but done without criminal intent, and to prevent other harm. Nothing is an offence merely by reason of its being done with the knowledge that it is likely to cause harm, if it be done without any criminal intention to cause harm, and in good faith for the purpose of preventing or avoiding other harm to person or property. Explanation. [cite_start]It is a question of fact in such a case whether the harm to be prevented or avoided was of such a nature and so imminent as to justify or excuse the risk of doing the act with the knowledge that it was likely to cause harm. [cite: 358, 359]

metadata.section_title: Act likely to cause harm, but done without criminal intent, and to prevent other harm.

page_content: ng the act with the knowledge that it was likely to cause harm. [cite: 358, 359] Illustrations:

metadata.section_title: Act likely to cause harm, but done without criminal intent, and to prevent other harm.

page_content: the knowledge that it was likely to cause harm. [cite: 358, 359] Illustrations: (a) A, the captain of a steam vessel, suddenly and without any fault or negligence on his part, finds himself in such a position that, before he can stop his vessel, he must inevitably run down a boat B, with twenty or thirty passengers on board. unless he changes the course of his vessel, and that, by changing his course, he must incur risk of running down a boat C with only two passengers on board, which he may possibly clear. [cite_start]Here, if A alters his course without any intention to run down the boat C and in good faith for the purpose of avoiding the danger to the passengers in the boat B, he is not guilty of an offence, though he may run down the boat C by doing an act which he knew was likely to cause that effect, if it be found as a matter of fact that the danger which he intended to avoid was such as to excuse him in incurring the risk of running down C. [cite: 361, 362, 363]

metadata.section_title: Act likely to cause harm, but done without criminal intent, and to prevent other harm.

page_content: as to excuse him in incurring the risk of running down C. [cite: 361, 362, 363] (b) A, in a great fire, pulls down houses in order to prevent the conflagration from spreading. He does this with the intention in good faith of saving human life or property. [cite_start]Here, if it be found that the harm to be prevented was of such a nature and so imminent as to excuse A's act, A is not guilty of the offence. [cite: 364, 365, 366]

metadata.section_title: Act likely to cause harm, but done without criminal intent, and to prevent other harm.

page_content: Section 83: Act of a child above seven and under twelve of immature understanding. Nothing is an offence which is done by a child above seven years of age and under twelve, who has not attained sufficient maturity of understanding to judge of the nature and consequences of his conduct on that occasion. [cite: 370]

metadata.section_title: Act of a child above seven and under twelve of immature understanding.

page_content: 84 IPC 84 S. 84 Sec 84 Section 84

metadata.section_title: Act of a person of unsound mind.

page_content: Section 84: Act of a person of unsound mind. Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law. [cite: 371]

metadata.section_title: Act of a person of unsound mind.

page_content: Summary: Section 85: Act of a person incapable of judgment by reason of intoxication caused against his will.

metadata.section_title: Act of a person incapable of judgment by reason of intoxication caused against his will.

page_content: Section 85: Act of a person incapable of judgment by reason of intoxication caused against his will.

page_content: 85 IPC 85 S. 85 Sec 85 Section 85

metadata.section_title: Act of a person incapable of judgment by reason of intoxication caused against his will.

page_content: Section 85: Act of a person incapable of judgment by reason of intoxication caused against his will. Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, is, by reason of intoxication, incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong, or contrary to law; provided that the thing which intoxicated him was administered to him without his knowledge or against his will. [cite: 372, 373]

metadata.section_title: Act of a person incapable of judgment by reason of intoxication caused against his will.

page_content: Summary: Section 86: Offence requiring a particular intent or knowledge committed by one who is intoxicated.

metadata.section_title: Offence requiring a particular intent or knowledge committed by one who is intoxicated.

page_content: Section 86: Offence requiring a particular intent or knowledge committed by one who is intoxicated.

metadata.section_title: Offence requiring a particular intent or knowledge committed by one who is intoxicated.

page_content: 86 IPC 86 S. 86 Sec 86 Section 86

metadata.section_title: Offence requiring a particular intent or knowledge committed by one who is intoxicated.

page_content: Section 86: Offence requiring a particular intent or knowledge committed by one who is intoxicated. In cases where an act done is not an offence unless done with a particular knowledge or intent, a person who does the act in a state of intoxication shall be liable to be dealt with as if he had the same knowledge as he would have had if he had not been intoxicated, unless the thing which intoxicated him was administered to him without his knowledge or against his will. [cite: 374]

metadata.section_title: Offence requiring a particular intent or knowledge committed by one who is intoxicated.

page_content: Summary: Section 87: Act not intended and not known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt, done by consent.

metadata.section_title: Act not intended and not known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt, done by consent.

page_content: Section 87: Act not intended and not known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt, done by consent.

metadata.section_title: Act not intended and not known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt, done by consent.

page_content: 87 IPC 87 S. 87 Sec 87 Section 87

metadata.section_title: Act not intended and not known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt, done by consent.

page_content: Section 87: Act not intended and not known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt, done by consent. Nothing which is not intended to cause death, or grievous hurt, and which is not known by the doer to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt, is an offence by reason of any harm which it may cause, or be intended by the doer to cause, to any person, above eighteen years of age, who has given consent, whether express or implied, to suffer that harm; or by reason of any harm which it may be known by the doer to be likely to cause to any such person who has consented to take the risk of that harm. [cite: 376, 378, 379]

metadata.section_title: Act not intended and not known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt, done by consent.

page_content: ch person who has consented to take the risk of that harm. [cite: 376, 378, 379] Illustrations: A and Z agree to fence with each other for amusement. [cite_start]This agreement implies the consent of each to suffer any harm which in the course of such fencing, may be caused without foul play; and if A, while playing fairly, hurts Z, A commits no offence. [cite: 381, 382, 383]

metadata.section_title: Act not intended and not known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt, done by consent.

page_content: Summary: Section 88: Act not intended to cause death, done by consent in good faith for person's benefit.

metadata.section_title: Act not intended to cause death, done by consent in good faith for person's benefit.

page_content: Section 88: Act not intended to cause death, done by consent in good faith for person's benefit.

metadata.section_title: Act not intended to cause death, done by consent in good faith for person's benefit.

page_content: 88 IPC 88 S. 88 Sec 88 Section 88

metadata.section_title: Act not intended to cause death, done by consent in good faith for person's benefit.

page_content: Section 88: Act not intended to cause death, done by consent in good faith for person's benefit. Nothing, which is not intented to cause death, is an offence by reason of any harm which it may cause, or be intended by the doer to cause, or be known by the doer to be likely to cause, to any person for whose benefit it is done in good faith, and who has given a consent, whether express or implied, to suffer that harm, or to take the risk of that harm. [cite: 384] Illustrations:

metadata.section_title: Act not intended to cause death, done by consent in good faith for person's benefit.

page_content: o suffer that harm, or to take the risk of that harm. [cite: 384] Illustrations: A, a surgeon, knowing that a particular operation is likely to cause the death of Z, who suffers under the painful complaint, but not intending to cause Z's death, and intending, in good faith, Z's benefit, performs that operation on Z, with Z's consent. [cite_start]A has committed no offence. [cite: 386, 387]

metadata.section_title: Act not intended to cause death, done by consent in good faith for person's benefit.

page_content: Summary: Section 89: Act done in good faith for benefit of child or insane person, by or by consent of guardian.

metadata.section_title: Act done in good faith for benefit of child or insane person, by or by consent of guardian.

page_content: Section 89: Act done in good faith for benefit of child or insane person, by or by consent of guardian.

metadata.section_title: Act done in good faith for benefit of child or insane person, by or by consent of guardian.

page_content: 89 IPC 89 S. 89 Sec 89 Section 89

metadata.section_title: Act done in good faith for benefit of child or insane person, by or by consent of guardian.

page_content: Section 89: Act done in good faith for benefit of child or insane person, by or by consent of guardian. Nothing which is done in good faith for the benefit of a person under twelve years of age, or of unsound mind, by or by consent, either express or implied, of the guardian or other person having lawful charge of that person, is an offence by reason of any harm which it may cause, or be intended by the doer to cause or be known by the doer to be likely to cause to that person: Provided-

metadata.section_title: Act done in good faith for benefit of child or insane person, by or by consent of guardian.

page_content: to cause or be known by the doer to be likely to cause to that person: Provided- Provisos. First. [cite_start]That this exception shall not extend to the intentional causing of death, or to the attempting to cause death; [cite: 389] Secondly. [cite_start]That this exception shall not extend to the doing of anything which the person doing it knows to be likely to cause death, for any purpose other than the preventing of death or grievous hurt, or the curing of any grievous disease or infirmity; [cite: 390]

metadata.section_title: Act done in good faith for benefit of child or insane person, by or by consent of guardian.

page_content: r grievous hurt, or the curing of any grievous disease or infirmity; [cite: 390] Thirdly. [cite_start]That this exception shall not extend to the voluntary causing of grievous hurt, or to the attempting to cause grievous hurt, unless it be for the purpose of preventing death or grievous hurt; or the curing of any grievous disease or infirmity; [cite: 391, 392] Fourthly. [cite_start]That this exception shall not extend to the abetment of any offence, to the committing of which offence it would not extend. [cite: 393] Illustrations:

metadata.section_title: Act done in good faith for benefit of child or insane person, by or by consent of guardian.

page_content: the committing of which offence it would not extend. [cite: 393] Illustrations: A, in good faith, for his child's benefit without his child's consent, has his child cut for the stone by a surgeon knowing it to be likely that the operation will cause the child's death, but not intending to cause the child's death. [cite_start]A is within the exception, inasmuch as his object was the cure of the child. [cite: 395, 396]

metadata.section_title: Act done in good faith for benefit of child or insane person, by or by consent of guardian.

page_content: Summary: Section 90: Consent known to be given under fear or misconception.

metadata.section_title: Consent known to be given under fear or misconception.

page_content: Section 90: Consent known to be given under fear or misconception.

metadata.section_title: Consent known to be given under fear or misconception.

page_content: 90 IPC 90 S. 90 Sec 90 Section 90

metadata.section_title: Consent known to be given under fear or misconception.

page_content: Section 90: Consent known to be given under fear or misconception. A consent is not such a consent as is intended by any section of this Code, if the consent is given by a person under fear of injury, or under a misconception of fact, and if the person doing the act knows, or has reason to believe, that the consent was given in consequence of such fear or misconception; or Consent of insane person. if the consent is given by a person who, from unsoundness of mind, or intoxication, is unable to understand the nature and consequence of that to which he gives his consent; or Consent of child. unless the contrary appears from the context, if the consent is given by a person who is under twelve years of age. [cite: 398, 399, 400, 401, 402]

metadata.section_title: Consent known to be given under fear or misconception.

page_content: Summary: Section 91: Exclusion of acts which are offences independently of harm cause.

metadata.section_title: Exclusion of acts which are offences independently of harm cause.

page_content: Section 91: Exclusion of acts which are offences independently of harm cause.

metadata.section_title: Exclusion of acts which are offences independently of harm cause.

page_content: 91 IPC 91 S. 91 Sec 91 Section 91

metadata.section_title: Exclusion of acts which are offences independently of harm cause.

page_content: Section 91: Exclusion of acts which are offences independently of harm cause. The exceptions in sections 87, 88 and 89 do not extend to acts which are offences independently of any harm which they may cause, or be intended to cause, or be known to be likely to cause, to the person giving the consent, or on whose behalf the consent is given. [cite: 404] Illustrations:

metadata.section_title: Exclusion of acts which are offences independently of harm cause.

page_content: the consent, or on whose behalf the consent is given. [cite: 404] Illustrations: Causing miscarriage (unless caused in good faith for the purpose of saving the life of the woman) is an offence independently of any harm which it may cause or be intended to cause to the woman. [cite_start]Therefore, it is not an offence "by reason of such harm"; and the consent of the woman or of her guardian to the causing of such miscarriage does not justify the act. [cite: 406, 407, 408]

metadata.section_title: Exclusion of acts which are offences independently of harm cause.

page_content: Summary: Section 92: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent.

metadata.section_title: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent.

page_content: Section 92: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent.

metadata.section_title: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent.

page_content: 92 IPC 92 S. 92 Sec 92 Section 92

metadata.section_title: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent.

page_content: Section 92: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent. Nothing is an offence by reason of any harm which it may cause to a person for whose benefit it is done in good faith, even without that person's consent, if the circumstances are such that it is impossible for that person to signify consent, or if that person is incapable of giving consent, and has no guardian or other person in lawful charge of him from whom it is possible to obtain consent in time for the thing to be done with benefit: Provided-

metadata.section_title: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent.

page_content: sible to obtain consent in time for the thing to be done with benefit: Provided- Provisos. First. [cite_start]That this exception shall not extend to the intentional causing of death, or the attempting to cause death; [cite: 411] Secondly. [cite_start]That this exception shall not extend to the doing of anything which the person doing it knows to be likely to cause death, for any purpose other than the preventing of death or grievous hurt, or the curing of any grievous disease or infirmity; [cite: 412]

metadata.section_title: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent.

page_content: r grievous hurt, or the curing of any grievous disease or infirmity; [cite: 412] Thirdly. [cite_start]That this exception shall not extend to the voluntary causing of hurt, or to the attempting to cause hurt, for any purpose other than the preventing of death or hurt; [cite: 413] Fourthly. [cite_start]That this exception shall not extend to the abetment of any offence, to the committing of which offence it would not extend. [cite: 414] Explanation. [cite_start]Mere pecuniary benefit is not benefit within the meaning of sections 88, 89 and 92. [cite: 428] Illustrations:

metadata.section_title: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent.

page_content: benefit within the meaning of sections 88, 89 and 92. [cite: 428] Illustrations: (a) Z is thrown from his horse, and is insensible. A, a surgeon, finds that Z requires to be trepanned. A, not intending Z's death, but in good faith, for Z's benefit, performs the trepan before Z recovers his power of judging for himself. [cite_start]A has committed no offence. [cite: 416, 417, 418]

metadata.section_title: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent.

page_content: dging for himself. [cite_start]A has committed no offence. [cite: 416, 417, 418] (b) Z is carried off by a tiger. A fires at the tiger knowing it to be likely that the shot may kill Z, but not intending to kill Z, and in good faith intending Z's benefit. A's ball gives Z a mortal wound. [cite_start]A has committed no offence. [cite: 419, 420]

metadata.section_title: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent.

page_content: gives Z a mortal wound. [cite_start]A has committed no offence. [cite: 419, 420] (c) A, a surgeon, sees a child suffer an accident which is likely to prove fatal unless an operation be immediately performed. There is no time to apply to the child's guardian. A performs the operation in spite of the entreaties of the child, intending, in good faith, the child's benefit. [cite_start]A has committed no offence. [cite: 421, 422, 423, 424]

metadata.section_title: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent.

page_content: ld's benefit. [cite_start]A has committed no offence. [cite: 421, 422, 423, 424] (d) A is in a house which is on fire, with Z, a child. People below hold out a blanket. A drops the child from the house stop, knowing it to be likely that the fall may kill the child, but not intending to kill the child, and intending, in good faith, the child's benefit. [cite_start]Here, even if the child is killed by the fall, A has committed no offence. [cite: 425, 426, 427]

metadata.section_title: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent.

page_content: Summary: Section 93: Communication made in good faith.

metadata.section_title: Communication made in good faith.

page_content: Section 93: Communication made in good faith.

metadata.section_title: Communication made in good faith.

page_content: 93 IPC 93 S. 93 Sec 93 Section 93

metadata.section_title: Communication made in good faith.

page_content: Section 93: Communication made in good faith. No communication made in good faith is an offence by reason of any harm to the person to whom it is made, if it is made for the benefit of that person. [cite: 429] Illustrations: A, a surgeon, in good faith, communicates to a patient his opinion that he cannot live. The patient dies in consequence of the shock. [cite_start]A has committed no offence, though he knew it to be likely that the communication might cause the patient's death. [cite: 431, 432]

metadata.section_title: Communication made in good faith.

page_content: Summary: Section 94: Act to which a person is compelled by threats.

metadata.section_title: Act to which a person is compelled by threats.

page_content: Section 94: Act to which a person is compelled by threats.

metadata.section_title: Act to which a person is compelled by threats.

page_content: 94 IPC 94 S. 94 Sec 94 Section 94

metadata.section_title: Act to which a person is compelled by threats.

page_content: Section 94: Act to which a person is compelled by threats. Except murder, and offences against the State punishable with death, nothing is an offence which is done by a person who is compelled to do it by threats, which, at the time of doing it, reasonably cause the apprehension that instant death to that person will otherwise be the consequence: Provided the person doing the act did not of his own accord, or from a reasonable apprehension of harm to himself short of instant death, place himself in the situation by which he became subject to such constraint. Explanation 1. A person who, of his own accord, or by reason of a threat of being beaten, joins a gang of dacoits, knowing their character, is not entitled to the benefit of this exception, on the ground of his having been compelled by his associates to do anything that is an offence by law. [cite_start]Explanation 2.-A person seized by a gang of dacoits, and forced, by threat of instant death, to do a thing which is an offence by law; for example, a smith compelled to take his tools and to force the door of a house for the dacoits to enter and plunder it, is entitled to the benefit of this exception. [cite: 433, 434, 435, 436, 437]

metadata.section_title: Act to which a person is compelled by threats.

page_content: Summary: Section 95: Act causing slight harm.

metadata.section_title: Act causing slight harm.

page_content: Section 95: Act causing slight harm.

metadata.section_title: Act causing slight harm.

page_content: 95 IPC 95 S. 95 Sec 95 Section 95

metadata.section_title: Act causing slight harm.

page_content: Section 95: Act causing slight harm. Nothing is an offence by reason that it causes, or that it is intended to cause, or that it is known to be likely to cause, any harm, if that harm is so slight that no person of ordinary sense and temper would complain of such harm. [cite: 438]

metadata.section_title: Act causing slight harm.
